#Text=The Canadian

#Text=The Canadian ( French : Le Canadien ) is a passenger train route operated by Via Rail Canada running from Toronto to Vancouver , with numerous intermediate stops including Winnipeg , Saskatoon , Edmonton , Jasper and Kamloops .
#Text=The trip , which takes over three days , is the longest passenger train route in North America , and covers several distinct landscapes .

#Text=It runs from Toronto 's financial district , through the sprawling suburbs of the Greater Toronto area , passing Ontario 's Lake Country and through the massive Canadian Shield , the open expanse of the prairies , across the Rocky Mountains , and into the lush Fraser Valley of British Colombia , before ending in the bustling Pacific city of Vancouver .
#Text=Understand

#Text=The Canadian is the longest scheduled passenger train outside Eurasia , and at 4,466 km , it is 542 km longer than the California Zephyr , and 114 km longer than the Indian Pacific in Australia , though it is less than half the distance of the Moscow-Vladivostok Trans-Siberian Railway .

#Text=The train inherited its name from a previous service operated by the Canadian Pacific Railway , which ran from Toronto to Vancouver , albeit on a more southern route that ran through Thunder Bay , Calgary and Banff .
#Text=The current route is largely that used by the rival Canadian National Railway 's Super Continental .

#Text=After both railways turned their passenger service over to Via in the 1970s , Via operated both trains until the southern route was mostly cancelled in the 1990s due to budget cuts , and the Canadian brand was transferred to the northern route .
#Text=The train operates using an assortment of cars used on the original Canadian and cars of the same era purchased from US railways .
#Text=The cars , mostly built in the 1950s , have been rebuilt several times and while quaint , are functional and have been modernized to a limited degree .
#Text=During the summer months , when demand is higher , the train will be longer than 20 cars .

#Text=While the train is dominated by tourists , especially in the summer , one of its purposes is to provide transportation services to the remote communities between Capreol and Winnipeg , and thus it makes many stops in remote places along the line .
#Text=Service on the train and major stations is available in English and French , all staff will speak English and most will speak French as well .
#Text=With a few exceptions the communities served by the train are primarily English-speaking .
#Text=Tickets

#Text=Tickets can be purchased directly from Via Rail through its website , over the phone ( ☏ +1888 842-7245 ( in Canada and the United States ) , +1 514 989 2626 ( worldwide ) , +1 800 268-9503 ( TTY ) ) , in person at any staffed Via station counter , or through overseas travel agents .
#Text=Unlike European rail tickets , the ticket is valid only for a specific date of departure .
#Text=See the sleep section of this article for a breakdown of classes and full prices .
#Text=Discounts

#Text=Sales and special online discounts are available through sporadically on Via 's website for both economy and sleeper tickets , but unless there is a general sale , discounts for the next few weeks of travel in economy class are available every week Tuesday Toronto ( Eastern ) Time .
#Text=Sleeper class discount fares are available on a separate page at any time .
#Text=Especially in the off season these sales can halve the base fare .
#Text=Via sometimes offers $ 15 fares for children age 11 and under between any two points on the route during the peak season .
#Text=Boarding

#Text=For passengers getting on in Toronto , Sudbury Junction , Capreol , Winnipeg , Saskatoon , Edmonton , Jasper or Vancouver , this is simply a matter of showing up at the station at the right time and if necessary checking your baggage at the baggage counter .
#Text=In Toronto , sleeper class passengers have access to the Business class lounge .

#Text=As Toronto is the only station on the route with frequent departures of other trains , economy passengers leaving Toronto should make sure that they get in the right line in the station concourse .
#Text=At all other stations boarding is simply a matter of waiting until the train arrives .
#Text=Depending on the station , there my be a building for you to wait in , washrooms and a wheelchair lift , passengers should check the station 's page on Via 's website .
#Text=Many remote stations will only have a signpost , and some not even that .
#Text=Passengers check the status of their train ahead of time .
#Text=When the train approaches at a remote station , stand a safe distance from the tracks , but so the conductor can see you .
#Text=Approach the conductor when they beckon or turn a flashlight on you .
#Text=They may ask you to take your baggage to the baggage car yourself and will help you board the train .
#Text=At most remote stations you are on railway property and should abide by the directions of railway staff , though they will typically leave you alone if you keep out of their way .
#Text=Route
#Text=This description may not reflect what is visible on the train , some areas will inevitably be covered by darkness as the train passes through them .
#Text=Westbound travellers should read the travel guide in reverse .
#Text=Vancouver-Gifford
#Text=Vancouver is the third largest metropolitan area in the country , with a population of 3.4 million .
#Text=The Canadian 's eastbound journey begins ( and the westbound ends ) at ( 4,466 km/3 days , 19h to Toronto , 0 km/0h from Vancouver , Time zone : Pacific )
#Text=Neoclassical Pacific Central Station , located just east of the downtown core .
#Text=It uses the BNSF tracks through suburban communities including Burnaby , to New Westminster .
#Text=After the train crosses the New Westminster Bridge , the Canadian leaves BNSF for CN tracks east .
#Text=From New Westminster to Gifford , the route passes railway yards and industry .
#Text=Fraser and Thompson River Canyons
#Text=At Gifford , the train diverts from the CN mainline and crosses the Fraser River to Mission .
#Text=CN and CPR utilize directional running through the Fraser and Thompson River canyons ; eastbound trains use the CPR lines and westbounds the CN tracks .
#Text=Thus , for the section through the two canyons , the Canadian runs on its original CPR route .
#Text=From Mission to Cisco , the CPR runs west ( north ) of the river ; afterwards , it runs east ( south ) .
#Text=Near Basque , the eastbound Canadian transfers onto the CN main .
#Text=Westbound , the Canadian stays on the CN tracks all the way into Vancouver .
#Text=The CN route passes through Painted Canyon , and features CN 's 240 m steel-arched bridge over the Fraser River and the CPR mainline at Cisco .
#Text=The tracks in Painted Canyon are only approximately 60 m above the Thompson River .
#Text=After Cisco , the CN mainline stays of the east/south side of the Fraser River all the way to the New Westminster Bridge , where the two routes merge .
#Text=On their regular schedules , both east and westbound Canadian 's travel through the Fraser and Thompson river canyons at night .
